text: hi everyone don't think liv tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new war on
drugs album i don't live here anymore
this is the latest full-length lp from
grammy award-winning philly band adam
grandu seals the war on drugs now on
their fifth full-length lp the war on
drugs have built up a pretty strong
stable of indie cred over the past
decade with one critically acclaimed
album after another i myself have been
at least somewhat enamored with the
band's creative fusions of psychedelic
rock kraut rock folk rock and americana
especially on their 2014 record lost in
the dream ironically my least favorite
record of their so far is the one they
won a best rock album grammy for a
deeper understanding where i thought the
songs weren't nearly as compelling as
the hazy and colorful sounds that
surrounded them but i think the band is
trying to change that dynamic a bit on i
don't live here anymore as here they're
kind of dropping a lot of the
psychedelic touches and more hypnotic
repetitions within their music instead
we're kind of turning up the springsteen
vibes turning up the tom petty vibes
which were always there but now are just
louder and what's also louder in the mix
is adam himself no longer sounding just
like a disembodied vocal in
the mix he is really with this newfound
clarity to these songs trying to take
the mantle of an honest to god front man
the vocals on this one are right up
front and center but as a singer and a
lyricist i think adam still has a ways
to go if
those elements are going to be kind of
carrying these tunes the opening track
living proof for example kind of runs
like a very tepid dillon impression
backed with mellow slow building folk
rock it's pretty while it's on but
there's no serious spark going on with
this track melodically or emotionally
meanwhile cuts like harmonia's dream
have more of a new wave pep in their
step the springsteen influence on this
one is in full force it almost feels
like uh when arcade fire was going
through their springsteen phase on the
suburbs but yeah this thing is an
exciting and driving piece of heartland
rock with lots of sparkling
instrumentation surrounding it but i
feel like the harder adam pushes it
vocally on this track the more apparent
his somewhat meek limitations become i'm
not so much hearing where his voice is
as much as i'm hearing where it's
definitely not going to go the track
change has more of a jangle pop quality
to it the bass and guitars and drums
sound so pristine i want to lick them
the vocals have more of a tom petty
angle to them which i think is more
fitting for adam's range the vocal
performance on this one pretty much goes
off without a hitch the next few numbers
on this record do ride a little rough
though the introduction to i don't want
to wait feels like i'm listening to a
bizarro version of phil collins in the
air tonight and it doesn't get any more
pleasant as adam's vocals come in and
sound like he's trying to do asmr
through like a drive-through speaker
eventually the track does reach this a
grand finish a piece of shimmering 80s
rock it's fine but man does this track
not start in a great place then victims
got more of a groovy electronic and
spacious quality to it maybe you could
say this cut would sound more
comfortable on one of the earlier war on
drugs records this track also just
happens to sport one of the worst mixes
on the lp as there are numerous points
where the vocals and shrill synthesizers
and i guess whooshing effects pile up
into what sounds like white noise it's
very staticky and not exactly alluring
adam's muttered and kind of sneaky vocal
leads on this one feel a little out of
place too in a somewhat amateurish way
it's like the deeper i go into this
record the more it feels like something
i would hear uploaded to that uncharted
zone youtube channel the delectable phil
thomas cat here
i feel old things do pick up on the
title track of the lp though it's more
heartland rock with an arena's worth of
atmosphere on it more of a dylan style
warble on the vocals too which i guess
is fitting considering the moment adam
sings about seeing dylan live anyway the
song shoots for sounding epic but mostly
just comes across mushy as the
instrumentation layers on i will say
adam does save a few of the best cuts
for last there's old skin i love the way
this tracks very delicate and pensive
intro busts into these hard rocking
layers of guitar and piano and drums
with adam singing on top of it with a
very strong vibrato coming across with
lots of emotion and conviction
definitely more of an impression being
left here than on some of the milder uh
singing on the rest of the lp i also
like the song's lyrical sentiment about
moving on changing uh giving up or being
tired of the old ways of life then
there's also wasted which also kicked
ass another great peppy fusion of
heartland rock and new wave the whole
thing is like this grand rustic
epic soup of sound some endearingly
lovesick lyrics from adam as well i
think his expressiveness on this track
makes up for his vocal range a lot but
to point to the singing again on the
following rings around my father's eyes
yeah here adam comes across
a little too rough but i do think the
organs make for a very heavenly sound
here and i do like his lyrics about
aging moving into the great beyond
there's a solid lyrical showing on the
closer occasional reign as well even
though the instrumental here as far as
heartland rock goes maybe a little dime
a dozen i still do like what adam says
here about feeling lost and frankly that
turn of phrase if loving you is the same
it's only some occasional rain is great
this track and a few others do a great
job of sending across this sentiment
that yeah sometimes things are hard but
that doesn't mean the overall journey
isn't worth it so yes overall i don't
live here anymore while i'm not in love
with this lp it's not too bad i may even
enjoy it more than the last war on drugs
record and in a way i do appreciate the
change of pace and the change of sound
and how the band has really kind of put
those vocals and the lyrics and the
storytelling more up front but even
though i respect the band here for
rearranging their sound and trying to
you know find a different appeal in the
process of that the singing and the
storytelling could certainly see some
improvements feeling a strong five to a
light six on this one tran position have
you given this album a listen did you
love it did you hate it what would you
rate it you're the best you're the best
what should i review next hit the like
if you like please subscribe and please
don't cry hit the bell as well over here
next to my head is another link that you
can hit up check that out or you know
the subscription button subscribe
channel yeah
we're on drugs anthony fantano forever
